A number of houses, roads and bridges partially damaged in Manukan, Bacungan and Zamboanga City. ([UN DHA, 15 Jun 1990](https://reliefweb.int/node/36447))

name: China: Floods - Jun 1990
description:
From 6 to 8 and 11 to 15 June, torrential rains with a maximum precipitation of 489 mm resulted in widespread floods in 39 counties of Hunan province. ([UN DHA, 19 Jun 1990](https://reliefweb.int/node/35070)) A UNDRO/UNDP resident representative reported an updated estimate of damage by the Ministry of Civil Affairs on 21 June as follows: 229 people died; 3,297 were injured; about 350,000 people were rendered homeless; and 20 million people were affected. ([UN DHA, 21 Jun 1990](https://reliefweb.int/node/35070))

Between 20-23 June, six other counties of Hunan province were hit by violent rain storms. 34 persons were reported dead, 1,399 injured and 510,000 were seriously affected. A UNDRO/UNDP resident representative reported an updated estimate of damage by the Ministry of Civil Affairs on 3 July as follows: 264 dead; 3,775 injured; 71,400 houses collapsed and 159,000 were damaged. ([UN DHA, 5 Jul 1990](https://reliefweb.int/node/35070))

New floods hit Hunan province from 25 June to 2 July 1990. According to Chinese authorities, the total damage caused by floods in the province was as follows: 88 counties/cities with 26 million people were affected; 363 people died; 5,805 were injured; 110,000 rooms collapsed; 23,730 rooms were damaged and crops on one million ha were destroyed.  ([UN DHA, 19 Jul 1990](https://reliefweb.int/node/35070))

name: Indonesia: Floods and Landslides - Feb 1990
description: Following torrential rains which caused serious floods in central java since end of last week, landslides hit several areas (Gura Bessi Village, North Jayapura district and Irian Jaya). Due to peak of rainy season, more rains expected.  UNDP/UNDRO Resident Representative reported following casualties and damages: death toll 169. Population affected 21,000. Houses destroyed/damaged 7,600. Agricultural land inundated by water 12,000 hectares. ([UN DHA, 2 Feb 1990](https://reliefweb.int/node/35316))

name: India: Floods - Aug 1989
description: Torrential monsoon rainstorms with winds of up to 75 km/h and floods from 23 to 31 July affected some coastal areas. Damage to crops, cattle heads, and immovable property was estimated at several million rupees. The death toll rose to over 800 in Maharashtra, 144 in Andhra Pradesh, 24 in Gujarat, and 73 in other districts. About 550 people were missing in Maharashtra. ([UN DHA, 3 Aug 1989](https://reliefweb.int/node/35038))

name: Bangladesh: Floods - Aug 1989
description: Following excessive rainfall in neighboring countries, flash floods occurred in the Sylhet district. The affected Upazilas are Zakiganj, Kanaighat, Bianibazar, and Golapgang. The most affected was Zakiganj where a break in the embankment caused a rush of water from the Kushiara river.  200,000 people in the above-mentioned Upazilas were affected. There were also reportedly flash floods in Bandarban district, and a tidal surge in Cox's Bazar and Chittagong districts. ([UN DHA, 14 Aug 1989](https://reliefweb.int/node/35312))

name: China: Floods and Landslides - Jul 1989
description:
Heavy rains poured on Sichuan province from 7 to 10 July. The  maximum rainfall recorded was 500 mm in Wushen county. Floods and landslides occurred in several areas. Chongqing city in Sichuan was the most seriously affected. In Huaying city of Sichuan province, a landslide with 1 million cubic meters at 1,000 meter long and 600 meter high engulfed 2 villages and 6 working units. ([UN DHA, 27 July 1989](https://reliefweb.int/node/35118))

The latest data is as follows: 2,000 people died; more than 10,000 were injured; and 100 million were affected (of which 60 million seriously); 1.2 million houses collapsed and 2.78 million were damaged; and more than 8.5 million ha of farmland was damaged. ([UN DHA, 6 Sep 1989](https://reliefweb.int/node/35118))

name: Sri Lanka: Floods - Jun 1989
description:
The UNDP/UNDRO resident representative reports heavy rains during the past several days which caused floods and landslides in the southwestern part of Sri Lanka. The worst affected area was Bulathkohupitiya in the Kegalle district. Other affected districts were Eliya, Gampaha, Galle, Kalutara, Matara, Nuwara and Ratnapura. ([UN DHA, 6 Jun 1989](https://reliefweb.int/node/34776))

According to the UNDP/UNDRP resident representative, the latest official estimates show more than 300 dead and 300,000 homeless. ([UN DHA, 8 Jun 1989](https://reliefweb.int/node/34776))

With receding flood waters, victims in the Colombo area who were previously housed in temples and schools are preparing to return to their houses. The number of affected persons in the most affected districts (Colombo, Galle, Gampaha, Kalutara, Kegalle, Ratnapura) is now estimated at 250,000. ([UN DHA, 9 Jun 1989](https://reliefweb.int/node/34776))

name: Philippines: Floods - Feb 1989
description:
Following continuous rain due to a low-pressure zone for the past 6 weeks, areas of Sorsogon, Camarines Sur and Samar have been hit by flash floods.  ([UN DHA, 6 Feb 1989](https://reliefweb.int/node/36462))

The Office of Civil Defence updated the damage as follows: 39 dead, 11 injured, 5 missing; over 260,000 people affected; more than 2,500 houses totally/partially destroyed; and total damage estimated at approximately US dollars 6 million ([UN DHA, 9 Feb 1989](https://reliefweb.int/node/36462))

name: Indonesia: Floods and Landslides - Jan 1989
Thailand: Floods and Mudslides - Nov 1988
description: Torrential monsoon rains triggered major mudslides in the region of Nakhon Si Thammarat province in the South of Thailand. The government indicated that there were 334 dead, 1,878 injured and 330 missing amongst a total of 978,232 affected (including 43,349 displaced). Material damage included 51,250 houses, 3,802 roads, 833 bridges, 144 dykes and 618 schools. ([UN DHA, 27 November 1988](https://reliefweb.int/node/34558))

name: India: Floods - Oct 1988
description: Continuous torrential rains in the hills since 21 September caused heavy floods in northwestern India. Vast areas in Punjab, Haryana, Himachal Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, and Delhi were inundated causing widespread loss of life, damage to crops/property, and paralysing surface and air traffic. The media reported that the death toll reached 174 in four affected states.  In Haryana, Yamuna river has flooded 25 villages in Jagadhri subdivision. In Delhi, the river Yamuna was flowing well above the danger mark and has flooded a number of colonies and transportation networks close to the river from where more than 16,000 people were evacuated to temporary camps. ([UN DHA, 4 Oct 1988](https://reliefweb.int/node/35060))

name: India: Floods - Aug 1988
description: Monsoon rains caused flooding in Brahmaputra and Ganges and their tributaries resulting in a disaster situation in north-eastern India. The States of Uttar Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, west Bengal and Arunachal Pradesh were affected. According to press reports, flooding claimed more than 850 lives. In Uttar Pradesh alone, 453 deaths were officially reported. 12,373 villages and 1.7 million hectares of land were affected.  In Assam, the army rescued 15,000 people from a flood-hit area in Gauhati on 29/30 August. The surging Brahmaputra and other rivers have affected 5.6 million people. The Assam death toll increased to 46. Displaced people were accommodated in 25 relief camps. In Bihar state, swollen Ganges and Kosi flooded 100 villages while Bagmati and Adhwara rivers flooded vast areas. 14 deaths were reported from West Bengal. ([UN DHA, 31 Aug 1988](https://reliefweb.int/node/35056))

name: China: Floods in Shanxi Province - Aug 1988
description: More than 30 counties have been hit by hailstorms since mid-June. in Lanxi, 903 persons were injured, with 170,000 people, 102 villages, and 67,700 hectares of farmland affected. More than 15 cities and counties were hit by rainstorms between 13-18 July. 18 persons were injured. Floods have ruined 345 houses, and 10,000 hectares of farmland. Inundations in 6 towns and 59,000 houses damaged dozens of water conservation facilities. ([UN DHA, 18 Aug 1988](https://reliefweb.int/node/35143))

name: Bangladesh: Floods - Aug 1988
description:
Following heavy rains and floods in the last two weeks of August: 125 people died; 13 million people were affected; 35 districts out of 64, areas of 25,000 sq.km. were affected; 370,000 ha of crop areas were fully and 391,000 ha were partially damaged. ([UN DHA, 30 Aug 1988](https://reliefweb.int/node/34551)) 

The official death toll is now over 500, many due to snakebites, drinking contaminated water, and consuming rotten foodstuffs. ([UN DHA, 5 Sep 1988](https://reliefweb.int/node/34551))

name: China: Floods in Zhejiang Province - Aug 1988
description: On 29 - 30 July, heavy rains caused violent floods in Zhejiang province, southeast China. In 12 hours rainfall reached 350-400 mm. 11 counties and cities were affected. The hardest hit was Ningbo city with 256 dead, 347 missing, and 200 injured, 120,000 people were stranded in an inaccessible area. 30,000 houses collapsed. 73,000 ha of farmland was flooded including 28,000 ha destroyed. Water in the affected area was contaminated and poisoned by rotting corpses and farm chemicals. Drinking water was in great shortage and freshwater from other places was not sufficient. ([UN DHA, 4 Aug 1988](https://reliefweb.int/node/35141))

name: Bangladesh: Floods - Jul 1988
description: Multiple flash floods, caused by heavy rains in north-east Bangladesh, are seriously affecting 7 districts: Sunamganj, Netrokona, Satkhira, Bogra, Moulavibazar, Habiganj, and Rangpur. So far 61 people were reported dead with damages to standing crops estimated at over 120,000 ha. ([UN DHA, 12 Jul 1988](https://reliefweb.int/node/35337))

name: Afghanistan: Floods - Jun 1988
description: In June 1988, major floods affected provinces of Badakhshan, Herat and Jouzjan in addition to Kabul, Takhar, Samangan, Baghlan. The government reports that 3,457 houses were totally and 1,570 partially devastated, and an estimated 40,000 people, thousand of hectares of cropland, irrigation system and hundreds of km of roads were affected. Total damages estimated by the government were US$260 million. The government has asked UNDRO to launch an appeal for international assistance. The government identified needs for 161,000 victims, including 32,000 children ([UN DHA, 27 July 1988](https://reliefweb.int/node/34446))

name: China: Floods - May 1988
description:
In Fujian province (in particular in counties Jianyang, Chongan, Zhenge), heavy rains caused floods since 20 May.  The rain continued as of 24 May with rainfall recorded up to 257 millimeters on 21 May. ([UN DHA, 24 May 1988](https://reliefweb.int/node/35139))

Updated information indicates a steep rise in the population affected: 91 deaths, 657 injured, 1 missing, 100,000 people in unreachable areas, and 100,000 displaced. 6,000 houses collapsed and there was damage to 3,908 kilometers of roads, 715 bridges, and 5,937 units of water supply system. The total loss was estimated to be up to 72 million US dollars. ([UN DHA, 27 May 1988](https://reliefweb.int/node/35139))

name: Indonesia: Floods - Nov 1987
description: Heavy monsoon rains have caused floods and landslides in Aceh province, northern Sumatra. Official reports indicate serious losses in crops, unhusked rice, and livestock. Damages were reported as follows: important road cuts in Central province, many houses either destroyed or seriously damaged, 4 persons killed by landslides, and several thousand persons were evacuated. ([UN DHA, 4 Nov 1987](https://reliefweb.int/node/35329))

name: Nepal: Floods - Aug 1987
description: Following torrential rain, for the past two weeks, extensive flood and landslide damage has been reported throughout the country. Particularly affected are central and eastern Terai districts and Central Hills. In addition to the damage to crops, houses, public infrastructure (mainly transportation), and private property, many families were rendered homeless. ([UN DHA, 14 Aug 1987](https://reliefweb.int/node/35593))

name: China: Floods - May 1987
description: Serious flooding has occurred in Guangdong province in southern China. Up to 70 deaths have been reported, and more than 10,000 hectares of farmland involving 31 villages were reported to be under water in the worst affected area, Zhangpu County. An assessment indicated the possibility of 158,000 hectares of farmland swamped and 5,300 houses washed away. 350,000 people were evacuated to safe areas. Guangzhou city reported that these were the worst floods since 1974 and 4 major rivers in provinces were flowing at two metres above the danger level. ([UN DHA, 26 May 1987](https://reliefweb.int/node/35123))

name: Bangladesh: Floods - Sep 1986
description:
A UNDRO/UNDP resident representative reported that serious flooding was caused by incessant rain during the last four days throughout the country. The south-western districts of Khulna, Bagerhat, Sathkhira, Pathuakhali, and Barguna were reported to be seriously affected areas. ([UN DHA, 30 Sep 1986](https://reliefweb.int/node/35346))

Approximately 3.4 million people were affected by flooding in 2,890 sq. miles in 25 districts. 30 total deaths were reported, mostly due to drowning or injuries from collapsed houses. Crops were damaged in approximately 1.3 million acres, mainly in the greater districts of Khulna, Jessore, and Faridpur. ([UN DHA, 10 Oct 1986](https://reliefweb.int/node/35346))

name: Bangladesh: Floods - Aug 1986
description: A UNDRO/UNDP resident representative in Dhaka reported that floods were caused by monsoon rains in the Ganges basin in the north-western Bangladesh district of Rajshahi. The water rose sharply in the last two weeks and flooded 1600 sq miles affecting 100,000 people. Four persons were reportedly killed and 48,500 acres of crops were damaged. ([UN DHA, 11 Aug 1986](https://reliefweb.int/node/35345))

name: Sri Lanka: Floods and Landslides - Feb 1986
description: Heavy rains in many parts of the country in early January caused floods in eastern and landslides in central provinces. The UNDRO resident representative transmitted the following government figures given on 12/2/86: 43 deaths, 12,897 families affected, 3,030 houses completely destroyed, and 19,250 houses partially damaged. ([UN DHA, 17 Feb 1986](https://reliefweb.int/node/34775))

name: China: Floods - Aug 1985
description: A UNDRO resident representative reports a flood disaster in Liaoning province. 200 people were killed, 100 were missing, and more than 1 million hectares of farmland were submerged. More than 10,000 troops were watching day and night on the banks of the Liaohe and emergency measures were taken to contain water in four reservoirs on the upper reaches of the Liaohe River. Most of those whose houses were flooded were evacuated to safe places. ([UN DHA, 30 Aug 1985](https://reliefweb.int/node/35135))

name: Chad: Floods in Am Timan - Jul 1985
Algeria: Floods - Jan 1985
description: On 9 January 1985, heavy snow and rain storms were reported in northeastern Algeria, causing scattered flooding.  Reported were 26 deaths and 3,000 homeless. [OCHA, 09 Jan 1985](https://reliefweb.int/node/34507)

name: Sri Lanka: Monsoon Floods - Jul 1984
description: The UNDRO/UNDP resident representative in Colombo reports that excessive monsoon rains have caused floods in the districts of Ratnapura, Kegalce, Gampaka, and Colombo. Preliminary information indicates 3 deaths, 14,000 families homeless, and over 1,500 houses destroyed. ([UN DHA, 14 Jul 1984](https://reliefweb.int/node/34785))

name: Bangladesh: Floods - May 1984
description:
Widespread heavy rains from 6-19 May, which was termed unprecedented according to meteorological records, caused severe flooding in eastern Bangladesh. Rain-swollen rivers burst their banks and overflowed into villages and inundated vast areas of agricultural land. Extensive damage to crops and property were reported. Thousands of people were rendered homeless and a greater number suffered heavy losses. The death toll was reported as 91 in Bangladesh. ([UN DHA, 25 May 1984](https://reliefweb.int/node/35336))

The most seriously affected areas were Mousavi, Bazar, Sylhet, Sunamganj and Habigunj.([UN DHA, 6 Jun 1984](https://reliefweb.int/node/35336))

name: Indonesia: Floods and Landslides - Mar 1984
description: The Indonesian govt national coordination board for natural disaster relief (Bakornas PBA) has advised the UNDRO/UNDP resident representative Jakarta of serious seasonal flooding and landslides in the provinces of central, east, and west Java, Jogyakarta special region, and north Sumatra. Twenty-six persons were reported dead, over 300,000 persons were affected, over 60,000 homes were damaged or destroyed, and approximately 31,000 hectares of rice fields were lost. ([UN DHA, 1 Mar 1984](https://reliefweb.int/node/35382))
